Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Synchronizing Video Imagery with Wearable Sensor Data and Side-by-Side Modeling Software to Develop Healthy Habits in Children Who Participate in Sports
Award.AbstractNarration:
This STTR Phase I project will develop Android and Apple iPhone apps to allow for mobile-enabled, rapid correction of improper or dangerous techniques in sports activities. The project goal is to eliminate dangerous, unhealthy behaviors in young athletes and replace them with non-damaging skills and techniques. In its simplest form, the technology presents a player with a video clip of their own behavior, paired with head impact data measured using worn sensors and physics-based simulations showing what occurs in the brain during dangerous hits. The quantitative biomechanical data is used to predict possible functional brain deficits and presented to the user in an age-appropriate manner. By combining a mouth guards with sensors, sideline video replay technology, physics-based brain simulations, on-line instruction and observational learning, coaches and trainers will be able to correct dangerous techniques and behaviors in sports activity as they occur. Coaches and trainers will also be able to show players video of their own technique following a significant impact to the head next to a synchronized clip of an athlete completing the same movements, but with no head impact. As a result, children and adolescents will learn there is never an acceptable level of head contact. Whether applied to football, hockey, lacrosse, soccer or one of any number of physical activities, this coaching tool will provide immediate instruction and self-reinforcing behavior modification.

The proposed technology enables unprecedented resolution of the biomechanical response during sports activities by combining synchronized video, wearable impact sensors and physics-based simulations that will identify dangerous incidents, with the goal of obtaining real time technique modification and therefore a dramatic reduction in the occurrence of injury. It is important to note that while sensor technology and analytical methods have advanced dramatically in the last several years, the integration of synchronized video technology would be a critical tool in helping players understand and prevent dangerous head impacts from occurring in contact sports. The mobile apps will be an innovative approach to reducing the number and severity of concussive and sub concussive blows to the head. Integrating sensor data, synchronized with video technology and physics-based impact simulations showing what occurs in the brain during dangerous impacts into a mobile app is innovative to the sporting industry and offers an opportunity to improve player safety in sports. The broader impact of the system is to show students and athletes dangerous techniques as soon as they occur along side of how their behavior could be modified, which will reduce the occurrence of serious injuries in sports and fitness pursuits causing health-enhancing activities to be rendered much safer.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Phase I Significant Results:

With support from a NSF STTR Phase I grant (Award #1622894), Penn State University and CoachSafe PlaySafe LLC created the CoachSafe PlaySafe mobile app to allow users (e.g. coaches, trainers, and players) to use smartphones, iPhones, Window’s phones, iPads or tablet computers from the field of play to immediately review potentially dangerous behavior based on data collected and integrated from biomechanical sensors, live video recording and computational simulations of the intracranial response.

A software application (i.e. an app) was developed that will enable coaches, trainers and parents to receive rapid notification of potential dangerous impacts sustained during a sporting event.  Accompanying these notifications is a video that merges three data streams together including 1) wearable biomechanical sensor data, 2) video clip of the play, and 3) a physics-based simulation showing the intracranial brain response. All three data streams are time synced with high accuracy.

These time-synced videos, and this merging of various advanced technologies, applied to an important problem of concussions in youth sports has many benefits including,

  • Provides a recorded “sideline view” of the impact event(s) which includes biomechanical measurements and an estimate of how external impacts are transferred into the brain
  • Can be digitally stored and shared
  • Helps coaches maximize their coachable moments.
  • Can be provided to a medical physician via email (enabling telemedicine-based technologies)
  • Can be used as a tool to change dangerous behavior of student-athletes in order to play more safely.
  • Provides technology that students can use that can be leveraged to engage them in learning physics, neuroscience, engineering, computer science, and health care. 

Moving Forward – Plan for Phase II

On December 29, 2017, CoachSafe PlaySafe LLC, CEO, Randall Bukowski and Sunburst Digital Inc., CEO, Ken Leonard, CEO signed an agreement making CoachSafe PlaySafe LLC a controlled subsidiary of Sunburst Digital.  Our purpose is to introduce awareness, knowledge, training and education to school districts and youth sports while bringing innovative concussion prevention technologies to the field.  We believe the CSPS Concussion Continuum will change behaviors and reduce the incidence of needless concussions that can lead to diminished lives and potential. 

With support from Sunburst Digital Inc., a highly respected digital content and curriculum publishing company (e.g. Sunburst’s digital curriculum is being used in over 95 percent of USA schools), CoachSafe PlaySafe will build upon the technology developed from the NSF STTR Phase I grant (Award #1622894) and develop a research based, Concussion Continuum that will provide schools, educators, students, families and athletic professionals with brain health and concussion awareness solutions in the classroom and on the field while inclusively serving the whole educational community.  Curriculum instructional designers will be provided by Sunburst Digital to support and assist CoachSafe PlaySafe in the development of the Continuum. Additionaly, CoachSafe PlaySafe LLC and Penn State University plan to submit a NSF STTR Phase II proposal in February of 2018.
